text: relation.  Here and there, a funeral procession was slowly on its way,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in weird contrast to the gaiety of the hour.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: The two companions, of course, read the epitaphs as they strolled
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: along.  In one, reminding them of the poet's--Si lacrimae prosunt,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: visis te ostende videri!--a woman prayed that her lost husband might
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: visit her dreams.  Their characteristic note, indeed, was an imploring
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: cry, still [143] to be sought after by the living.  "While I live,"
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: such was the promise of a lover to his dead mistress, "you will receive
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: this homage: after my death,--who can tell?"--post mortem nescio.  "If
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: ghosts, my sons, do feel anything after death, my sorrow will be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: lessened by your frequent coming to me here!"  "This is a privileged
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: tomb; to my family and descendants has been conceded the right of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: visiting this place as often as they please."  "This is an eternal
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: habitation; here lie I; here I shall lie for ever." "Reader! if you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: doubt that the soul survives, make your oblation and a prayer for me;
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and you shall understand!"
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: The elder of the two readers, certainly, was little affected by those
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: pathetic suggestions.  It was long ago that after visiting the banks of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Padus, where he had sought in vain for the poplars (sisters of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Phaethon erewhile) whose tears became amber, he had once for all
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: arranged for himself a view of the world exclusive of all reference to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: what might lie beyond its "flaming barriers."  And at the age of sixty
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: he had no misgivings.  His elegant and self-complacent but far from
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: unamiable scepticism, long since brought to perfection, never failed
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: him.  It surrounded him, as some are surrounded by a magic ring of fine
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: aristocratic manners, with "a rampart," through which he himself never
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: broke, nor permitted any thing or person to break upon him.  Gay,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: animated, content with his old age [144] as it was, the aged student
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: still took a lively interest in studious youth.--Could Marius inform
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: him of any such, now known to him in Rome?  What did the young men
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: learn, just then? and how?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: In answer, Marius became fluent concerning the promise of one young
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: student, the son, as it presently appeared, of parents of whom Lucian
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: himself knew something: and soon afterwards the lad was seen coming
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: along briskly--a lad with gait and figure well enough expressive of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: sane mind in the healthy body, though a little slim and worn of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: feature, and with a pair of eyes expressly designed, it might seem, for
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: fine glancings at the stars.  At the sight of Marius he paused
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: suddenly, and with a modest blush on recognising his companion, who
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: straightway took with the youth, so prettily enthusiastic, the freedom
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of an old friend.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: In a few moments the three were seated together, immediately above the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: fragrant borders of a rose-farm, on the marble bench of one of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: exhedrae for the use of foot-passengers at the roadside, from which
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: they could overlook the grand, earnest prospect of the Campagna, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: enjoy the air.  Fancying that the lad's plainly written enthusiasm had
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: induced in the elder speaker somewhat more fervour than was usual with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: him, Marius listened to the conversation which follows.--
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: "Ah!  Hermotimus!  Hurrying to lecture! [145] --if I may judge by your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: pace, and that volume in your hand.  You were thinking hard as you came
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: along, moving your lips and waving your arms.  Some fine speech you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: were pondering, some knotty question, some viewy doctrine--not to be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: idle for a moment, to be making progress in philosophy, even on your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: way to the schools.  To-day, however, you need go no further.  We read
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: a notice at the schools that there would be no lecture.  Stay
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: therefore, and talk awhile with us.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --With pleasure, Lucian.--Yes!  I was ruminating yesterday's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: conference.  One must not lose a moment.  Life is short and art is
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: long!  And it was of the art of medicine, that was first said--a thing
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: so much easier than divine philosophy, to which one can hardly attain
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in a lifetime, unless one be ever wakeful, ever on the watch. And here
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the hazard is no little one:--By the attainment of a true philosophy to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: attain happiness; or, having missed both, to perish, as one of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: vulgar herd.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --The prize is a great one, Hermotimus! and you must needs be near it,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: after these months of toil, and with that scholarly pallor of yours.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Unless, indeed, you have already laid hold upon it, and kept us in the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: dark.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --How could that be, Lucian?  Happiness, as Hesiod says, abides very
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: far hence; and the way to it is long and steep and rough.  I see myself
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: still at the beginning of my journey; still [146] but at the mountain's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: foot.  I am trying with all my might to get forward.  What I need is a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: hand, stretched out to help me.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And is not the master sufficient for that?  Could he not, like Zeus
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in Homer, let down to you, from that high place, a golden cord, to draw
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you up thither, to himself and to that Happiness, to which he ascended
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: so long ago?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --The very point, Lucian!  Had it depended on him I should long ago
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: have been caught up.  'Tis I, am wanting.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well! keep your eye fixed on the journey's end, and that happiness
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: there above, with confidence in his goodwill.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Ah! there are many who start cheerfully on the journey and proceed a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: certain distance, but lose heart when they light on the obstacles of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the way.  Only, those who endure to the end do come to the mountain's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: top, and thereafter live in Happiness:--live a wonderful manner of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: life, seeing all other people from that great height no bigger than
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: tiny ants.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --What little fellows you make of us--less than the pygmies--down in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the dust here.  Well! we, 'the vulgar herd,' as we creep along, will
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: not forget you in our prayers, when you are seated up there above the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: clouds, whither you have been so long hastening.  But tell me,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Hermotimus!--when do you expect to arrive there?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Ah! that I know not.  In twenty years, [147] perhaps, I shall be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: really on the summit.--A great while! you think.  But then, again, the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: prize I contend for is a great one.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Perhaps!  But as to those twenty years--that you will live so long.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Has the master assured you of that?  Is he a prophet as well as a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: philosopher?  For I suppose you would not endure all this, upon a mere
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: chance--toiling day and night, though it might happen that just ere the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: last step, Destiny seized you by the foot and plucked you thence, with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: your hope still unfulfilled.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Hence, with these ill-omened words, Lucian!  Were I to survive but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: for a day, I should be happy, having once attained wisdom.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --How?--Satisfied with a single day, after all those labours?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yes! one blessed moment were enough!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --But again, as you have never been, how know you that happiness is to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: be had up there, at all--the happiness that is to make all this worth
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: while?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --I believe what the master tells me.  Of a certainty he knows, being
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: now far above all others.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And what was it he told you about it?  Is it riches, or glory, or
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: some indescribable pleasure?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Hush! my friend!  All those are nothing in comparison of the life
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: there.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --What, then, shall those who come to the [148] end of this
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: discipline--what excellent thing shall they receive, if not these?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Wisdom, the absolute goodness and the absolute beauty, with the sure
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and certain knowledge of all things--how they are.  Riches and glory
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and pleasure--whatsoever belongs to the body--they have cast from them:
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: stripped bare of all that, they mount up, even as Hercules, consumed in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the fire, became a god.  He too cast aside all that he had of his
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: earthly mother, and bearing with him the divine element, pure and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: undefiled, winged his way to heaven from the discerning flame.  Even so
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: do they, detached from all that others prize, by the burning fire of a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: true philosophy, ascend to the highest degree of happiness.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Strange!  And do they never come down again from the heights to help
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: those whom they left below?  Must they, when they be once come thither,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: there remain for ever, laughing, as you say, at what other men prize?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --More than that!  They whose initiation is entire are subject no
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: longer to anger, fear, desire, regret.  Nay!  They scarcely feel at all.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well! as you have leisure to-day, why not tell an old friend in what
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: way you first started on your philosophic journey?  For, if I might, I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: should like to join company with you from this very day.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --If you be really willing, Lucian! you will learn in no long time your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: advantage over all [149] other people.  They will seem but as children,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: so far above them will be your thoughts.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well!  Be you my guide!  It is but fair.  But tell me--Do you allow
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: learners to contradict, if anything is said which they don't think
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: right?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --No, indeed!  Still, if you wish, oppose your questions.  In that way
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you will learn more easily.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Let me know, then--Is there one only way which leads to a true
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: philosophy--your own way--the way of the Stoics: or is it true, as I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: have heard, that there are many ways of approaching it?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yes!  Many ways!  There are the Stoics, and the Peripatetics, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: those who call themselves after Plato: there are the enthusiasts for
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Diogenes, and Antisthenes, and the followers of Pythagoras, besides
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: others.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --It was true, then.  But again, is what they say the same or different?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Very different.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yet the truth, I conceive, would be one and the same, from all of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: them.  Answer me then--In what, or in whom, did you confide when you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: first betook yourself to philosophy, and seeing so many doors open to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you, passed them all by and went in to the Stoics, as if there alone
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: lay the way of truth?  What token had you?  Forget, please, all you are
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to-day--half-way, or more, on the philosophic journey: [150] answer me
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: as you would have done then, a mere outsider as I am now.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Willingly!  It was there the great majority went!  'Twas by that I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: judged it to be the better way.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --A majority how much greater than the Epicureans, the Platonists, the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Peripatetics?  You, doubtless, counted them respectively, as with the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: votes in a scrutiny.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --No!  But this was not my only motive.  I heard it said by every one
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that the Epicureans were soft and voluptuous, the Peripatetics
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: avaricious and quarrelsome, and Plato's followers puffed up with pride.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: But of the Stoics, not a few pronounced that they were true men, that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: they knew everything, that theirs was the royal road, the one road, to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: wealth, to wisdom, to all that can be desired.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Of course those who said this were not themselves Stoics: you would
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: not have believed them--still less their opponents.  They were the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: vulgar, therefore.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --True!  But you must know that I did not trust to others exclusively.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: I trusted also to myself--to what I saw.  I saw the Stoics going
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: through the world after a seemly manner, neatly clad, never in excess,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: always collected, ever faithful to the mean which all pronounce
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: 'golden.'
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You are trying an experiment on me.  You would fain see how far you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: can mislead [151] me as to your real ground.  The kind of probation you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: describe is applicable, indeed, to works of art, which are rightly
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: judged by their appearance to the eye.  There is something in the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: comely form, the graceful drapery, which tells surely of the hand of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Pheidias or Alcamenes.  But if philosophy is to be judged by outward
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: appearances, what would become of the blind man, for instance, unable
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to observe the attire and gait of your friends the Stoics?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --It was not of the blind I was thinking.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yet there must needs be some common criterion in a matter so
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: important to all.  Put the blind, if you will, beyond the privileges of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: philosophy; though they perhaps need that inward vision more than all
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: others.  But can those who are not blind, be they as keen-sighted as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you will, collect a single fact of mind from a man's attire, from
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: anything outward?--Understand me!  You attached yourself to these
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: men--did you not?--because of a certain love you had for the mind in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: them, the thoughts they possessed desiring the mind in you to be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: improved thereby?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Assuredly!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --How, then, did you find it possible, by the sort of signs you just
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: now spoke of, to distinguish the true philosopher from the false?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Matters of that kind are not wont so to reveal themselves.  They are
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: but hidden mysteries, hardly to be guessed at through the words and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: acts which [152] may in some sort be conformable to them.  You,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: however, it would seem, can look straight into the heart in men's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: bosoms, and acquaint yourself with what really passes there.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You are making sport of me, Lucian!  In truth, it was with God's help
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: I made my choice, and I don't repent it.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And still you refuse to tell me, to save me from perishing in that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: 'vulgar herd.'
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Because nothing I can tell you would satisfy you.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You are mistaken, my friend!  But since you deliberately conceal the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: thing, grudging me, as I suppose, that true philosophy which would make
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: me equal to you, I will try, if it may be, to find out for myself the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: exact criterion in these matters--how to make a perfectly safe choice.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: And, do you listen.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --I will; there may be something worth knowing in what you will say.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well!--only don't laugh if I seem a little fumbling in my efforts.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: The fault is yours, in refusing to share your lights with me.  Let
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Philosophy, then, be like a city--a city whose citizens within it are a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: happy people, as your master would tell you, having lately come thence,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: as we suppose.  All the virtues are theirs, and they are little less
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: than gods.  Those acts of violence which happen among us are not to be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: seen in their streets.  They live together in one mind, very seemly;
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the things which beyond [153] everything else cause men to contend
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: against each other, having no place upon them.  Gold and silver,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: pleasure, vainglory, they have long since banished, as being
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: unprofitable to the commonwealth; and their life is an unbroken calm,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in liberty, equality, an equal happiness.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And is it not reasonable that all men should desire to be of a city
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: such as that, and take no account of the length and difficulty of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: way thither, so only they may one day become its freemen?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --It might well be the business of life:--leaving all else, forgetting
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: one's native country here, unmoved by the tears, the restraining hands,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of parents or children, if one had them--only bidding them follow the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: same road; and if they would not or could not, shaking them off,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: leaving one's very garment in their hands if they took hold on us, to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: start off straightway for that happy place! For there is no fear, I
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: suppose, of being shut out if one came thither naked.  I remember,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: indeed, long ago an aged man related to me how things passed there,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: offering himself to be my leader, and enrol me on my arrival in the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: number of the citizens.  I was but fifteen--certainly very foolish: and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: it may be that I was then actually within the suburbs, or at the very
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: gates, of the city. Well, this aged man told me, among other things,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that all the citizens were wayfarers from afar.  Among them were
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: barbarians and slaves, poor [154] men--aye! and cripples--all indeed
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: who truly desired that citizenship.  For the only legal conditions of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: enrolment were--not wealth, nor bodily beauty, nor noble
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: ancestry--things not named among them--but intelligence, and the desire
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: for moral beauty, and earnest labour.  The last comer, thus qualified,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: was made equal to the rest: master and slave, patrician, plebeian, were
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: words they had not--in that blissful place.  And believe me, if that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: blissful, that beautiful place, were set on a hill visible to all the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: world, I should long ago have journeyed thither.  But, as you say, it
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: is far off: and one must needs find out for oneself the road to it, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the best possible guide.  And I find a multitude of guides, who press
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: on me their services, and protest, all alike, that they have themselves
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: come thence.  Only, the roads they propose are many, and towards
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: adverse quarters.  And one of them is steep and stony, and through the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: beating sun; and the other is through green meadows, and under grateful
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: shade, and by many a fountain of water.  But howsoever the road may be,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: at each one of them stands a credible guide; he puts out his hand and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: would have you come his way.  All other ways are wrong, all other
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: guides false.  Hence my difficulty!--The number and variety of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: ways!  For you know, There is but one road that leads to Corinth.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well!  If you go the whole round, you [155] will find no better
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: guides than those.  If you wish to get to Corinth, you will follow the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: traces of Zeno and Chrysippus.  It is impossible otherwise.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yes!  The old, familiar language!  Were one of Plato's
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: fellow-pilgrims here, or a follower of Epicurus--or fifty others--each
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: would tell me that I should never get to Corinth except in his company.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: One must therefore credit all alike, which would be absurd; or, what is
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: far safer, distrust all alike, until one has discovered the truth.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Suppose now, that, being as I am, ignorant which of all philosophers is
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: really in possession of truth, I choose your sect, relying on
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: yourself--my friend, indeed, yet still acquainted only with the way of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Stoics; and that then some divine power brought Plato, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Aristotle, and Pythagoras, and the others, back to life again.  Well!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: They would come round about me, and put me on my trial for my
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: presumption, and say:--'In whom was it you confided when you preferred
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Zeno and Chrysippus to me?--and me?--masters of far more venerable age
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: than those, who are but of yesterday; and though you have never held
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: any discussion with us, nor made trial of our doctrine?  It is not thus
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that the law would have judges do--listen to one party and refuse to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: let the other speak for himself.  If judges act thus, there may be an
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: appeal to another tribunal.'  What should I answer?  Would it [156] be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: enough to say:--'I trusted my friend Hermotimus?'--'We know not
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Hermotimus, nor he us,' they would tell me; adding, with a smile, 'your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: friend thinks he may believe all our adversaries say of us whether in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: ignorance or in malice.  Yet if he were umpire in the games, and if he
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: happened to see one of our wrestlers, by way of a preliminary exercise,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: knock to pieces an antagonist of mere empty air, he would not thereupon
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: pronounce him a victor.  Well! don't let your friend Hermotimus
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: suppose, in like manner, that his teachers have really prevailed over
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: us in those battles of theirs, fought with our mere shadows.  That,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: again, were to be like children, lightly overthrowing their own
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: card-castles; or like boy-archers, who cry out when they hit the target
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of straw.  The Persian and Scythian bowmen, as they speed along, can
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: pierce a bird on the wing.'
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Let us leave Plato and the others at rest.  It is not for me to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: contend against them.  Let us rather search out together if the truth
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of Philosophy be as I say.  Why summon the athletes, and archers from
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Persia?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yes! let them go, if you think them in the way.  And now do you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: speak!  You really look as if you had something wonderful to deliver.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well then, Lucian! to me it seems quite possible for one who has
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: learned the doctrines of the Stoics only, to attain from those a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: knowledge [157] of the truth, without proceeding to inquire into all
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the various tenets of the others.  Look at the question in this way. If
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: one told you that twice two make four, would it be necessary for you to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: go the whole round of the arithmeticians, to see whether any one of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: them will say that twice two make five, or seven?  Would you not see at
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: once that the man tells the truth?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --At once.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Why then do you find it impossible that one who has fallen in with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Stoics only, in their enunciation of what is true, should adhere to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: them, and seek after no others; assured that four could never be five,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: even if fifty Platos, fifty Aristotles said so?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You are beside the point, Hermotimus!  You are likening open
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: questions to principles universally received.  Have you ever met any
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: one who said that twice two make five, or seven?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --No! only a madman would say that.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And have you ever met, on the other hand, a Stoic and an Epicurean
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: who were agreed upon the beginning and the end, the principle and the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: final cause, of things?  Never!  Then your parallel is false.  We are
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: inquiring to which of the sects philosophic truth belongs, and you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: seize on it by anticipation, and assign it to the Stoics, alleging,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: what is by no means clear, that it is they for whom twice two make
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: four.  But the Epicureans, or the Platonists, [158] might say that it
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: is they, in truth, who make two and two equal four, while you make them
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: five or seven.  Is it not so, when you think virtue the only good, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Epicureans pleasure; when you hold all things to be material, while
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Platonists admit something immaterial?  As I said, you resolve
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: offhand, in favour of the Stoics, the very point which needs a critical
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: decision.  If it is clear beforehand that the Stoics alone make two and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: two equal four, then the others must hold their peace.  But so long as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that is the very point of debate, we must listen to all sects alike, or
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: be well-assured that we shall seem but partial in our judgment.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --I think, Lucian! that you do not altogether understand my meaning. To
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: make it clear, then, let us suppose that two men had entered a temple,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of Aesculapius,--say! or Bacchus: and that afterwards one of the sacred
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: vessels is found to be missing.  And the two men must be searched to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: see which of them has hidden it under his garment.  For it is certainly
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in the possession of one or the other of them.  Well! if it be found on
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the first there will be no need to search the second; if it is not
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: found on the first, then the other must have it; and again, there will
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: be no need to search him.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Yes!  So let it be.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And we too, Lucian! if we have found the holy vessel in possession of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the Stoics, shall no longer have need to search other philosophers,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: [159] having attained that we were seeking.  Why trouble ourselves
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: further?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --No need, if something had indeed been found, and you knew it to be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that lost thing: if, at the least, you could recognise the sacred
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: object when you saw it.  But truly, as the matter now stands, not two
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: persons only have entered the temple, one or the other of whom must
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: needs have taken the golden cup, but a whole crowd of persons.  And
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: then, it is not clear what the lost object really is--cup, or flagon,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: or diadem; for one of the priests avers this, another that; they are
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: not even in agreement as to its material: some will have it to be of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: brass, others of silver, or gold.  It thus becomes necessary to search
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the garments of all persons who have entered the temple, if the lost
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: vessel is to be recovered.  And if you find a golden cup on the first
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of them, it will still be necessary to proceed in searching the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: garments of the others; for it is not certain that this cup really
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: belonged to the temple.  Might there not be many such golden
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: vessels?--No! we must go on to every one of them, placing all that we
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: find in the midst together, and then make our guess which of all those
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: things may fairly be supposed to be the property of the god. For,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: again, this circumstance adds greatly to our difficulty, that without
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: exception every one searched is found to have something upon him--cup,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: or flagon, or diadem, of brass, of silver, [160] of gold: and still,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: all the while, it is not ascertained which of all these is the sacred
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: thing.  And you must still hesitate to pronounce any one of them guilty
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of the sacrilege--those objects may be their own lawful property: one
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: cause of all this obscurity being, as I think, that there was no
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: inscription on the lost cup, if cup it was.  Had the name of the god,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: or even that of the donor, been upon it, at least we should have had
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: less trouble, and having detected the inscription, should have ceased
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to trouble any one else by our search.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --I have nothing to reply to that.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Hardly anything plausible.  So that if we wish to find who it is has
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the sacred vessel, or who will be our best guide to Corinth, we must
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: needs proceed to every one and examine him with the utmost care,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: stripping off his garment and considering him closely.  Scarcely, even
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: so, shall we come at the truth.  And if we are to have a credible
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: adviser regarding this question of philosophy--which of all
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: philosophies one ought to follow--he alone who is acquainted with the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: dicta of every one of them can be such a guide: all others must be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: inadequate.  I would give no credence to them if they lacked
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: information as to one only.  If somebody introduced a fair person and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: told us he was the fairest of all men, we should not believe that,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: unless we knew that he had seen all the people in the world.  Fair he
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: might be; but, fairest of all--none could [161] know, unless he had
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: seen all.  And we too desire, not a fair one, but the fairest of all.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Unless we find him, we shall think we have failed.  It is no casual
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: beauty that will content us; what we are seeking after is that supreme
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: beauty which must of necessity be unique.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --What then is one to do, if the matter be really thus?  Perhaps you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: know better than I.  All I see is that very few of us would have time
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to examine all the various sects of philosophy in turn, even if we
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: began in early life.  I know not how it is; but though you seem to me
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to speak reasonably, yet (I must confess it) you have distressed me not
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: a little by this exact exposition of yours.  I was unlucky in coming
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: out to-day, and in my falling in with you, who have thrown me into
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: utter perplexity by your proof that the discovery of truth is
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: impossible, just as I seemed to be on the point of attaining my hope.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Blame your parents, my child, not me!  Or rather, blame mother Nature
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: herself, for giving us but seventy or eighty years instead of making us
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: as long-lived as Tithonus.  For my part, I have but led you from
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: premise to conclusion.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Nay! you are a mocker!  I know not wherefore, but you have a grudge
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: against philosophy; and it is your entertainment to make a jest of her
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: lovers.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Ah!  Hermotimus! what the Truth may [162] be, you philosophers may be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: able to tell better than I.  But so much at least I know of her, that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: she is one by no means pleasant to those who hear her speak: in the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: matter of pleasantness, she is far surpassed by Falsehood: and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Falsehood has the pleasanter countenance.  She, nevertheless, being
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: conscious of no alloy within, discourses with boldness to all men, who
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: therefore have little love for her.  See how angry you are now because
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: I have stated the truth about certain things of which we are both alike
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: enamoured--that they are hard to come by.  It is as if you had fallen
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in love with a statue and hoped to win its favour, thinking it a human
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: creature; and I, understanding it to be but an image of brass or stone,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: had shown you, as a friend, that your love was impossible, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: thereupon you had conceived that I bore you some ill-will.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --But still, does it not follow from what you said, that we must
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: renounce philosophy and pass our days in idleness?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --When did you hear me say that?  I did but assert that if we are to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: seek after philosophy, whereas there are many ways professing to lead
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: thereto, we must with much exactness distinguish them.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well, Lucian! that we must go to all the schools in turn, and test
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: what they say, if we are to choose the right one, is perhaps
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: reasonable; but surely ridiculous, unless we are to live as [163] many
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: years as the Phoenix, to be so lengthy in the trial of each; as if it
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: were not possible to learn the whole by the part!  They say that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Pheidias, when he was shown one of the talons of a lion, computed the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: stature and age of the animal it belonged to, modelling a complete lion
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: upon the standard of a single part of it.  You too would recognise a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: human hand were the rest of the body concealed. Even so with the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: schools of philosophy:--the leading doctrines of each might be learned
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: in an afternoon.  That over-exactness of yours, which required so long
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: a time, is by no means necessary for making the better choice.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You are forcible, Hermotimus! with this theory of The Whole by the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Part.  Yet, methinks, I heard you but now propound the contrary.  But
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: tell me; would Pheidias when he saw the lion's talon have known that it
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: was a lion's, if he had never seen the animal?  Surely, the cause of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: his recognising the part was his knowledge of the whole.  There is a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: way of choosing one's philosophy even less troublesome than yours. Put
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the names of all the philosophers into an urn.  Then call a little
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: child, and let him draw the name of the philosopher you shall follow
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: all the rest of your days.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Nay! be serious with me.  Tell me; did you ever buy wine?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Surely.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --And did you first go the whole round of [164] the wine-merchants,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: tasting and comparing their wines?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --By no means.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --No!  You were contented to order the first good wine you found at
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: your price.  By tasting a little you were ascertained of the quality of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the whole cask.  How if you had gone to each of the merchants in turn,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and said, 'I wish to buy a cotyle of wine.  Let me drink out the whole
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: cask.  Then I shall be able to tell which is best, and where I ought to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: buy.'  Yet this is what you would do with the philosophies.  Why drain
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the cask when you might taste, and see?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --How slippery you are; how you escape from one's fingers!  Still, you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: have given me an advantage, and are in your own trap.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --How so?
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Thus!  You take a common object known to every one, and make wine the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: figure of a thing which presents the greatest variety in itself, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: about which all men are at variance, because it is an unseen and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: difficult thing.  I hardly know wherein philosophy and wine are alike
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: unless it be in this, that the philosophers exchange their ware for
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: money, like the wine-merchants; some of them with a mixture of water or
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: worse, or giving short measure.  However, let us consider your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: parallel.  The wine in the cask, you say, is of one kind throughout.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: But have the philosophers--has your own [165] master even--but one and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: the same thing only to tell you, every day and all days, on a subject
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: so manifold?  Otherwise, how can you know the whole by the tasting of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: one part?  The whole is not the same--Ah! and it may be that God has
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: hidden the good wine of philosophy at the bottom of the cask.  You must
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: drain it to the end if you are to find those drops of divine sweetness
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you seem so much to thirst for!  Yourself, after drinking so deeply,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: are still but at the beginning, as you said.  But is not philosophy
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: rather like this?  Keep the figure of the merchant and the cask: but
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: let it be filled, not with wine, but with every sort of grain.  You
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: come to buy.  The merchant hands you a little of the wheat which lies
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: at the top.  Could you tell by looking at that, whether the chick-peas
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: were clean, the lentils tender, the beans full?  And then, whereas in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: selecting our wine we risk only our money; in selecting our philosophy
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: we risk ourselves, as you told me--might ourselves sink into the dregs
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of 'the vulgar herd.'  Moreover, while you may not drain the whole cask
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of wine by way of tasting, Wisdom grows no less by the depth of your
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: drinking.  Nay! if you take of her, she is increased thereby.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: And then I have another similitude to propose, as regards this tasting
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of philosophy.  Don't think I blaspheme her if I say that it may be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: with her as with some deadly poison, [166] hemlock or aconite. These
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: too, though they cause death, yet kill not if one tastes but a minute
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: portion.  You would suppose that the tiniest particle must be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: sufficient.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Be it as you will, Lucian!  One must live a hundred years: one must
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: sustain all this labour; otherwise philosophy is unattainable.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Not so!  Though there were nothing strange in that, if it be true, as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you said at first, that Life is short and art is long.  But now you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: take it hard that we are not to see you this very day, before the sun
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: goes down, a Chrysippus, a Pythagoras, a Plato.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --You overtake me, Lucian! and drive me into a corner; in jealousy of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: heart, I believe, because I have made some progress in doctrine whereas
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you have neglected yourself.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Well!  Don't attend to me!  Treat me as a Corybant, a fanatic: and do
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you go forward on this road of yours.  Finish the journey in accordance
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: with the view you had of these matters at the beginning of it.  Only,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: be assured that my judgment on it will remain unchanged. Reason still
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: says, that without criticism, without a clear, exact, unbiassed
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: intelligence to try them, all those theories--all things--will have
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: been seen but in vain.  'To that end,' she tells us, 'much time is
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: necessary, many delays of judgment, a cautious gait; repeated
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: inspection.'  And we are not to regard the outward appearance, or the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: reputation of wisdom, in any of the [167] speakers; but like the judges
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of Areopagus, who try their causes in the darkness of the night, look
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: only to what they say.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Philosophy, then, is impossible, or possible only in another life!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Hermotimus!  I grieve to tell you that all this even, may be in truth
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: insufficient.  After all, we may deceive ourselves in the belief that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: we have found something:--like the fishermen!  Again and again they let
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: down the net.  At last they feel something heavy, and with vast labour
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: draw up, not a load of fish, but only a pot full of sand, or a great
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: stone.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --I don't understand what you mean by the net.  It is plain that you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: have caught me in it.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Try to get out!  You can swim as well as another.  We may go to all
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: philosophers in turn and make trial of them.  Still, I, for my part,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: hold it by no mean certain that any one of them really possesses what
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: we seek.  The truth may be a thing that not one of them has yet found.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: You have twenty beans in your hand, and you bid ten persons guess how
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: many: one says five, another fifteen; it is possible that one of them
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: may tell the true number; but it is not impossible that all may be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: wrong.  So it is with the philosophers.  All alike are in search of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Happiness--what kind of thing it is.  One says one thing, one another:
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: it is pleasure; it is virtue;--what not?  And Happiness may indeed be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: one of those things.  But it is possible [168] also that it may be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: still something else, different and distinct from them all.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --What is this?--There is something, I know not how, very sad and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: disheartening in what you say.  We seem to have come round in a circle
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to the spot whence we started, and to our first incertitude. Ah!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Lucian, what have you done to me?  You have proved my priceless pearl
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: to be but ashes, and all my past labour to have been in vain.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: --Reflect, my friend, that you are not the first person who has thus
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: failed of the good thing he hoped for.  All philosophers, so to speak,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: are but fighting about the 'ass's shadow.'  To me you seem like one who
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: should weep, and reproach fortune because he is not able to climb up
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: into heaven, or go down into the sea by Sicily and come up at Cyprus,
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: or sail on wings in one day from Greece to India.  And the true cause
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of his trouble is that he has based his hope on what he has seen in a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: dream, or his own fancy has put together; without previous thought
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: whether what he desires is in itself attainable and within the compass
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of human nature.  Even so, methinks, has it happened with you.  As you
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: dreamed, so largely, of those wonderful things, came Reason, and woke
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you up from sleep, a little roughly: and then you are angry with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Reason, your eyes being still but half open, and find it hard to shake
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: off sleep for the pleasure of what you saw therein.  Only, [169] don't
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: be angry with me, because, as a friend, I would not suffer you to pass
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: your life in a dream, pleasant perhaps, but still only a dream--because
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: I wake you up and demand that you should busy yourself with the proper
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: business of life, and send you to it possessed of common sense.  What
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: your soul was full of just now is not very different from those Gorgons
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and Chimaeras and the like, which the poets and the painters construct
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: for us, fancy-free:--things which never were, and never will be, though
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: many believe in them, and all like to see and hear of them, just
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: because they are so strange and odd.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: And you too, methinks, having heard from some such maker of marvels of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: a certain woman of a fairness beyond nature--beyond the Graces, beyond
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Venus Urania herself--asked not if he spoke truth, and whether this
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: woman be really alive in the world, but straightway fell in love with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: her; as they say that Medea was enamoured of Jason in a dream. And what
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: more than anything else seduced you, and others like you, into that
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: passion, for a vain idol of the fancy, is, that he who told you about
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: that fair woman, from the very moment when you first believed that what
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: he said was true, brought forward all the rest in consequent order.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Upon her alone your eyes were fixed; by her he led you along, when once
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you had given him a hold upon you--led you along the straight road, as
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: he said, to the beloved one.  All was easy after that. [170] None of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: you asked again whether it was the true way; following one after
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: another, like sheep led by the green bough in the hand of the shepherd.
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: He moved you hither and thither with his finger, as easily as water
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: spilt on a table!
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: My friend!  Be not so lengthy in preparing the banquet, lest you die of
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: hunger!  I saw one who poured water into a mortar, and ground it with
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: all his might with a pestle of iron, fancying he did a thing useful and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: necessary; but it remained water only, none the less."
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Just there the conversation broke off suddenly, and the disputants
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: parted.  The horses were come for Lucian.  The boy went on his way, and
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: Marius onward, to visit a friend whose abode lay further.  As he
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: returned to Rome towards evening the melancholy aspect, natural to a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: city of the dead, had triumphed over the superficial gaudiness of the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: early day.  He could almost have fancied Canidia there, picking her way
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: among the rickety lamps, to rifle some neglected or ruined tomb; for
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: these tombs were not all equally well cared for (Post mortem nescio!)
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: and it had been one of the pieties of Aurelius to frame a severe law to
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: prevent the defacing of such monuments.  To Marius there seemed to be
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: some new meaning in that terror of isolation, of being left alone in
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: these places, of which the sepulchral inscriptions were so full.  A
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: blood-red sunset was dying angrily, and its wild glare upon the shadowy
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: objects around helped to combine [171] the associations of this famous
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: way, its deeply graven marks of immemorial travel, together with the
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: earnest questions of the morning as to the true way of that other sort
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of travelling, around an image, almost ghastly in the traces of its
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: great sorrows--bearing along for ever, on bleeding feet, the instrument
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter

text: of its punishment--which was all Marius could recall distinctly of a
title: Marius the Epicurean — Volume 2
author: Pater, Walter
